Drag0nFly:

this feature-request quickly devolved into how to think of intricate ways to degrade the video while spending precious cpu-hours on the server-side transcoding the video

No, all the transcoding would have to be done client-side, signal-server is unable to do it because all videos (like most everything else) are end2end encrypted.

There are three video use-cases which are supported in signalapp (android + ios + lin + win + osx) at the moment,

  • one is the quick-cam … currently ios-only … which is the most secure way to record video-clips because they are not written to disk unencrypted (unless demanded). These are recorded/transcoded entirely on the client-side, but transmitted via signal-server.

  • 2nd is the webrtc cryptocalling with video enabled … currently android&ios-only … which is used during cryptocalling, and is not recorded (no option for that yet), thus is never written to disk, AND on top of that is streaming p2p so it never goes through signal-server by default, unless one of the parties enables relay-all-calls

  • 3rd and finally, you are talking about the situation where you are utilizing the stock camera-app on a device, or an external video-creation / video-editing / video-transcoding tool, and you are thus in possession of a video-file. You can send this as a generic file-attachment from any platform, and the recipient will get it just like you sent it: that means, signalapp does NOT apply any transcoding, you probably DO have the video-clip written to disk at some point outside signalapp perimeter, and the recipient(s) may or may NOT be able to actually playback the content. Plus, of course, if they have an aspect-ratio different from the clip-format, will get letterboxing or some other kind of sender/recipient mismatch type thing.

Drag0nFly:

small matter of increasing an arcane limit of 100mb
to something more 21st century

Your specific feature-request, is not a small one. Easy to implement, but has downsides

  • you want signal-server to have a higher filesize cap. This has an impact on typeOne signal4ios quickcam usage, but because of the heavy compression, not much of one I suspect. The main use-case for that increase, is typeThree uncompressed video-clips which are created externally, and supported on all platforms (as far as transport is concerned …playback is another matter).

To me that is the Wrong Solution, because there is a lot of lag involved. You have to record the video, which takes you N minutes. You then have a 195 MiB video clip, which might take one minute or ten minutes to upload, depending on your network-connection. The file goes to signal-server. Your contact “Bob” then has to download, which is another (additional) ten seconds to a couple minutes, depending on his downlink speed. Finally, Bob has to hit play, and watch the video, which is another N minutes of time. Then he can respond: “hey that was hilarious” or whatever.

Better to have you stream the video to him, p2p == you start recording, your handset negotiates a webrtc streaming-connection with Bob’s handset (using a trivial amount of signal-server bandwidth for the setup process), and then while you record your handset streams the data to Bob’s handset which can playback instantly. Some lag still, but measured in seconds not minutes. And this is scalable: the lag (and the signal-server bandwidth costs) are the same, even if you are sending 9999 megs of video.

The downside to implementing the better solution, is that it is a large complex effort. Whereas, the easy solution is to change the current cap of “100 MiB” in some file on signal-server, to instead say “9999 MiB” instead. But that is expensive: signal foundation has to pay for bandwidth on the upload, and then more bandwidth on the download. It has to keep open sockets for a long duration, as well. Worse is the expense in reputation: some endusers think “hey a video-clip is a video-clip” and they get angry when it takes 30 minutes for their giant 4K 12bit-color masterpiece of a baby eating ice cream, to get sent over to gramma. The ice cream is all melted by the time gramma replies.

Drag0nFly:

originally submitted the feature enhancement to the Android

Yeah, they used to deal with feature-requests in github, but they’ve been trying (with varying degrees of success :-) for quite a long time now), to get featue-requests discussed here in the forums. Partly because, feature-requests that seem simple on first glance, are often not simple.

Drag0nFly:

phone produces gigabyte files

Yes, you only produced a fifth of a gigabyte in your example-file. Which is double the size of the current cap. You could get under the current cap, by splitting your clip into two segments, each 97 megs in filesize.

But you could also make a clip ten times that size, simply by recording more footage. If your 195 MB clip was 5 minutes duration, then a clip of one hour duration (such as a youtube show or something) would be roughly 2345 MB, assuming apples2apples

The reason for the cap, is not to keep you from sending your clip specifically, the reason is to keep signal-server from being clogged with people sending gigantic bluray rips (expensive in liability-worries and in webhosting-money), plus to keep everyday endusers who are wanting to send brief messenger-type clips to each other, happy. Not just happy they CAN send clips, but happy the clips download briskly and playback correctly and so on … even if they are on roaming dataplan whatever crappy-connection

Drag0nFly:

HD video “doesn’t make a difference on a phone screen”,
and I am not going to debate this further

You need not debate it further :-) but it is a valid point. 99% of signalapp endusers are smartphone endusers (because you have to link your signal4desktop to a master-device smartphone). That limits how huge of a video-file makes sense to allow: not just for dataplans, not just for teensy screen-sizes, but also for storage reasons. Filling up Bob’s phone with a large cap on video-clip sizes, will result in signalapp getting the blame, whether that is fair or not. So there are a bunch of reasons to have a cap of SOME kind, and yeah, it does seem a small cap by standards of current video-recording-cams that ship in high-end phones.

There are ways to get around the limitation though, such as firefoxSend or cryptomator+whatever or similar kinds of services. I agree that we eventually want signalapp to be able to junk the 100MB limitation, but it won’t happen instantaneously. The size-cap is not imposed arbitrarily for no reason.

posts.cooked:
Telegram is 1500 MiB and the only cost is lack of proper encryption

But generally speaking, most messengers are built with some kind of cap, because the cost of the upload and download is expensive in speed-reputation, and also in server-load.

Signalapp can use a few tricks to keep the speed-reputation high, and load small:

  • streaming, rather than record + save + upload + store + download + playback
  • p2p connections, rather than same-as-above
  • video transcoding (which is the way whatsapp does it: libvlc.so as of 2017 maybe)

The more people that are recipients though – such as a videoconf type or multicast type setup – the more advanced your technique has to be, if you want to handle the load in a way that does not bring SOME device to its knees (hurting your speediness rep)

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: WhatsApp uses another trick to limit server bandwidth: it stores only one copy of an attachment encrypted on the server and then sends out the key encrypted to all receivers. So in a groupchat it needs to store the bulk of the data (the attachment) only once, clients need to upload it only once, and the key is sent out e2e to all receivers (many messages but they are small, contain only the encrypted key and which attachment to download).

johanw666:

So in a groupchat [whatsapp] needs to store
the bulk of the data (the attachment) only once,
clients need to upload it only once

Signalapp also does this. Which is why I get annoyed when people say signalapp “only uses client-side fanout” when in fact signalapp does not do naive fanout. :-)

link_counts.title: Signal group messaging client side fanout vs server side fanout

posts.cooked: It is still client-side fanout though. Instead of attachment, it shares a link and a key through client side fanout.

Yes, I know you like that terminology But there is a difference between client-side fanout which is naive – and sends 99 copies of a 9MB attachment out – versus client-side fanout which is correctly implemented (sends one upload of the attachment and then 99 textual messages). Both signalapp and whatsapp upload the 9MB file once. Both signalapp and whatsapp use non-naive client-side-fanout when there is a group-update. Signalapp uses non-naive client-side-fanout for ALL other messages as well, whereas whatsapp sometimes optimizes away some of the traffic – at the cost of server-side metadata about groupchat memberships being more readily available (no timing analysis needed)

I don’t disagree it is still client-side fanout, just, it is not NAIVE client-side fanout
